desc: AXL, a receptor tyrosine kinase, is altered by mutation, amplification or overexpression in various cancers.

AXL encodes a receptor tyrosine kinase whose ligand is the vitamin K-dependent growth factor, GAS6. Signaling through AXL mediates proliferation, survival and chemoresistance in AXL-expressing cells (PMID: 23982172). This paracrine signaling axis regulates such diverse cellular functions through activation of the MAPK/ERK and PI3K/AKT signaling pathways (PMID: 18620092). Additionally, AXL has been shown to be essential to the epithelial-to-mesenchymal transition, thereby regulating breast cancer metastasis (PMID: 16585512). AXL is overexpressed in many human cancers including lung, breast and pancreatic cancer, and is a chronic myelogeneous leukemia-associated oncogene (PMID: 1656220). Currently, inhibitors specifically targeting AXL or multi-targeted kinase inhibitors with good potency against AXL are under clinical development (PMCID: PMC4259419).

articles.title: TAM receptor tyrosine kinases: biologic functions, signaling, and potential therapeutic targeting in human cancer.
articles.reference: Linger RM et al. Advances in cancer research. 2008;100()35-83.
